title: John Thomson credits NHS staff with saving his daughter's life after horror allergic reaction
text:

The daughter of Cold Feet actor John Thomson says she 'wouldn't be here' without the medics who saved her life after a terrifying allergic reaction as a child.

Olivia Thomson, 16, ended up in a high dependency unit after reacting badly to medication she received during an operation when she was younger.

Now Olivia and her dad have spoken publicly about her childhood health battles for the first time, as she prepares to take part in an event to thank the medics who saved her life.

The teenager had to undergo regular surgeries as a child, after being born with a benign epithelial tumour, which caused warts under her tongue and in her mouth which were removed in regular operations.

(Image: MEN Media)

Olivia said: "I grew up knowing that once or twice a year I’d be having an operation.

“It was hard as a kid, especially as I couldn’t really talk about it with other children – they would run away or pick on me because they thought it was weird.

Without these operations there was a strong chance they would have spread to her throat, meaning Olivia would have been at risk of choking or having breathing difficulties.

(Image: MEN Media )

But after one of the operations, her throat started to swell and she had to be rushed back to hospital by her mum, Sam.

"My ninth operation was the worst", said Olivia.

"I must have been allergic to one of the drugs I was given or something because I ended up on the high dependency unit.

"We’d actually gone home after the operation but then I felt my throat swelling up and I just said ‘Mummy, I need to go back to hospital’".

(Image: MEN Media)

Olivia credits the hospital's fast reaction for saving her life.

“If it wasn’t for the hospital, I wouldn’t be here.

“It was one of the scariest times of my life because I had no idea what was going on.”

Olivia was treated by the Starlight Unit, a satellite ward of Royal Manchester Children's Hospital, based on the Wythenshawe Hospital site.

John, who is a patron of RMCH and has recently appeared in the smash ITV drama A Confession, said: “The worst part of it all was seeing your baby being taken away. But she was always a trooper.

(Image: MEN Media)

“We grew used to the operations, but it never made that horrible feeling in the anaesthetic room any easier.

“But I definitely couldn’t fault the staff – they were all fantastic.”

She added: “I was in and out of the Starlight Unit to the point where I knew everyone’s name and they knew me.

“When dad recently hosted the NHS awards in Manchester, just how much the staff do for patients really hit home.

(Image: MEN Media)

“The condition I had is nothing compared to the severe cases they face each day. I have so much admiration for the work and miracles they have performed on so many children.

“So I joined Glow as a thank you to them all. It was also Royal Manchester Children’s Hospital’s 10th birthday this year, so I thought it might as well be this year.”

Olivia no longer needs operations, and has not visited the hospital regularly since she was 14.

Later this month, she will take part in Glow in the Park, a 5k night time run in Heaton Park in aid of the Royal Manchester Children's Hospital Charity, to thank the people who saved her life.

*Glow takes place on Saturday, October 26 in Heaton Park
description: The actor from Cold Feet and A Confession says his daughter would not be here today if it weren't for the quick-thinking NHS staff
